importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and development timeline of the Reefline project, which is in active planning and early implementation stages.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with initial phases beginning in 2025 and full realization anticipated by 2035.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef off Miami Beach designed to restore the island's lost coral habitat and serve as an underwater ecotourism destination.
The project integrates art and science, using marine-grade concrete sculptures—such as cars and starfish—to provide structure for coral growth.
Coral nursery operations led by Colin Foord involve growing over 2,000 soft coral specimens, including gorgonians, which will eventually be transplanted onto the reef.
The project is funded partially by a $5 million Miami Beach city bond approved by voters and aims to raise $6 million more for its first phase.

Artistic director Ximena Caminos, originally from Argentina, is a cultural placemaker who uses art to revitalize communities, applying that vision to create public underwater habitats for marine life.
Leandro Ehrlich, an internationally known artist, contributes sculptures that will be colonized by coral over time, transforming the art installations into living ecosystems.
The reef will be located approximately 15 to 20 feet deep and 700 feet off Miami Beach, making it accessible to swimmers without boats.
Reefline aims to restore a coral reef that once existed off Miami Beach until the 1970s, when it was buried by sand used to replenish the beach.
The project includes an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about the threats facing coral reefs globally.
Future phases may feature a constellation of 57 giant sculpted starfish, potentially becoming a symbolic icon for Miami.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef designed to restore a historically lost coral ecosystem. The project, led by artist and cultural placemaker Ximena Caminos and coral scientist Colin Foord, combines art and marine science to create an underwater ecotourism destination. Art installations, including 22 concrete-cast cars and a future constellation of 57 starfish, will serve as structural platforms for resilient corals such as gorgonians to grow. These corals, cultivated in a nursery, will transform the sculptures into living reefs, restoring marine biodiversity. The project, funded by a $5 million city bond and aiming for $6 million in additional funding, will be accessible to swimmers within 15 to 20 feet of the shore. It not only revives a once-vital reef but also serves as an educational tool and a potential cultural symbol for Miami Beach.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
